values:
Is this thing on?

PS, I'm now at RyanBrenizer.com/blog.

All of my photography-related updates will be here: http://www.amazon.com/ryanbrenizer I can only maintain so many sites effectively. Look for me at Amazon and Facebook. UPDATE: LJ users can follow the Amazon blog under the feed . Comments, should be left at the Amazon blog.

A New Beginning
Originally uploaded by carpe icthus.

Last May, I did some work with the Student Publishing Initiative, a fantastic institution that helps students make their own publications -- and we're talking real, page-turner books, not student newspapers. One of the projects was with Horizon Academy in Rikers Island Jail, and I recently found out that they're using my work to help convice inmates to go to school.

That is just so unbelievably freaking cool. I also recently completed a project that was the centerpiece of a successful proposal to get a school more than $200 million in badly needed funds, but something about this tugs at my heartstrings even more.

I've gotten publication clearance for the Rikers images, but for this use I figured I'd use an image that keeps the inmates anonymous.

Popular Photography pointed me to the site of Kathryn Obermaier and her fantastic documentary work on bodybuilders, interpreting the tension of their lives and skin in really interesting ways. She, unsurprisingly, is a graduate of the International Center of Photography, my favorite place on Earth to go when I need inspiration. Whether for a course or for a show, I've met so many dedicated, brilliant photographers there that I always leave itching to up my game. Definitely check out her work, as long as you're in a place and/or mental state where you're able to see men in extremely small bikini underwear.

Kiss by Dusk
Originally uploaded by carpe icthus.

You can guess from the perspective where I had to be standing to get the reflection right. Anything for the shot.

Amazon.com has been happy with the work I've been doing for their Amazon Daily blog, so they've given me my very own blog. I have some different options for output there, so I can feel fairly free to write about my experiences in the business of photography as well as general photography tips and news without spamming people who don't want to read about each wedding I shoot. This means a few things: People who want to follow my business, especially non-LiveJournal users, should probably follow it at that page. Here is a personalized RSS feed People who want to follow inane details of my personal life should get a LiveJournal account and have me add them as a contact, so that will not be syndicated. This is an exciting time. If you want to read my introductory post, go here.

Under the Lash
Originally uploaded by carpe icthus.

A quiet moment with the bride.

More wedding stuff to come in the next few weeks, including a proper blogging of the weddings I've shot this year.
The good news? One of my photos hit Digg, and got 50,000 new viewers in a few hours. The bad news? Out of all the work I've done, it's this photo.

By the Light of Night
Originally uploaded by carpe icthus.

The strapping groom from this past weekend's wedding, in virtually no light at all (about 1/6th of what you'd get if you were directly lit by a single candle). By no coincidence, my latest Amazon.com piece is about tips for shooting in low light.

It may seem strange that my favorite photography blog is written by someone who proudly professes to have no interest in being a photographer, but I've fallen in love with A Photo Editor. Admittedly, I'm probably the perfect market -- I have a lot of respect for magazine photography even when the final product leaves me dry, and the Myth-of-Sisyphus work ethic is right up my alley, the kind that will make someone shoot 700 perfectly exposed pictures, turn in 70 and grease-pencil 7 for one quarter-page photo, or do eight hours of set-up to make sure the client doesn't have to be on the set for more than three minutes. At the same time, I'm way too populist to give myself over to that world, so I don't have the bitterness that you see flaring up in the comments from photographers who A Photo Editor isn't hiring. In any case, it's provocative, insightful, funny, and a different kind of voice than you usually hear unless you're in that world.

I had total creative control here, and wanted to get beyond simple beauty to something more interesting. I still prefer to get away from backgrounds and out into the world, but it is nice to have outlets:
My latest Amazon article, "There's More than Pictures in Your Pictures", is up.

You gotta SHOUT!
Originally uploaded by carpe icthus.

Fordham University students rock the house at the annual President's Ball -- something which, I will pointedly note, we didn't have when I went there.

When Flickr's Colors Attack
Originally uploaded by carpe icthus.

An establishing shot for a campus party I was hired to shoot on Friday. This is the stuff that drives lenses mad.

All Lit Up
Originally uploaded by carpe icthus.

The one thing my motto -- "I shoot everything" -- had really been missing was extremely complicated lighting setups, mostly because I don't often have an extra $200,000 on me and a 5000 square foot studio. So I'm spending this week and next in an Advanced Studio Lighting class, and this is my favorite from yesterday.

Now You're a Man!
Originally uploaded by carpe icthus.

I shot my first bar mitzvah on Oct 13, and I really lucked out with this newly minted young adult. David is incredibly talented -- he played clarinet and keyboard with the band, and did a great job -- and just about the nicest 13-year-old I've ever come across, even when I was 13. The party had it all, too, from professional dancers to a casino to a fantastic view of the city. Congratulations, David!

Also, a funny story from the party. The DJ service had professional party guests -- basically attractive dancers there to make sure everyone was on the dance floor and having a good time. Now, every time I photograph someone for any reason, they stick in my head. Given that I take so many pictures in such a small area, I am filled with a perpetual sense of "Do I know you?" deja vu. Well, I kept getting that with one of the dancers, but it's really hard to ask "Do I know you from somewhere?" or especially "Have I taken a picture of you before?" without it seeming like a line. It wasn't until right after the party that it came to me -- she went to Columbia, and she was in a snapshot from a cocktail party three years ago. Yeah, that's my threshold for deja vu.

1) Meet Cass Bird. Look at her fantastic photography. Peruse her site. Then let me know if you think the top half of her gallery pages are intuitive to browse through. I have a personal stake in this. 2) I just delved into the EXIF of one of my cameras to see the shutter count, and since I got my first D200 I've taken about 90,000 images. With a VERY busy month to come and the D3 on its way, I should top off 100K by the end of the year without breaking a sweat. Not bad, considering I almost never use continuous shooting -- that's 100,000 iterations of focus, compose, press the shutter.

Shameless plug: Amazon articles up
Originally uploaded by carpe icthus.

The PhotoPlus Expo knew exactly how to draw photographers' attention -- scantily clad models -- so I'm borrowing from their playbook. The second part of my Amazon.com report from the Expo is up.

To the Stars!
Originally uploaded by carpe icthus.

The Gehry-designed Jay Pritzker Pavilion in Chicago.
New post up at Amazon: Greetings from the PhotoPlus Expo, including shots from the brand-new Olympus E-3 and Nikon's new 400mm f/2.8 VR lens. More to come.
That's the good news. The bad news? They didn't credit me.
Supporters and media look on as Teachers College Professor Madonna Constantine speaks at a rally of support after a noose was found hanging from her office doorknob.

At the Edge of the World
Originally uploaded by carpe icthus.

The Cloud Gate, literally.

This picture was just featured on Chicago-ist, making this the third "-ist" site to feature my work, after Gothamist and DCist.
Today is going to be an interesting day.

Greetings from Chicago Originally uploaded by carpe icthus.

Well, I just got back, so technically it's greetings from New York, but that would just be confusing. Also, congratulations to my friend Caroline Duffy, who was one of the ones who manged to finish the boiling hot Chicago Marathon before it descended into disarray. I had lunch with her the day after, and it's always interesting to see someone limp on both legs.

Portrait in Dreamland
Originally uploaded by carpe icthus.

From an extremely fun engagement shoot. (Note the ring)

Has anyone been having color space problems in Lightroom and/or CS3? My colors are washed out on the Web, definitely a color space issue, but I'm doing all the conversions correctly.

Scenes from a Protest
Originally uploaded by carpe icthus.

Photos from the protest are up. View them as a slideshow here.

Look kids, Mo Rocca!
Originally uploaded by carpe icthus.

A lot more from today's (right now's) protest of Columbia University inviting Iran's president to debate coming soon.

Bibliophiles in Love
Originally uploaded by carpe icthus.

Whenever I do an engagement shoot, I want something unique about the couple to show through. When this shoot started late because Korie and Jesse were in different parts of the park, happily engrossed in their respective books, I knew we'd have to do something with it.

A map that matters
Originally uploaded by carpe icthus.

Not a photo; just something I thought was cool. Google Maps has had a "My Maps" feature for a while that lets you put in locations that are important to you. To me, the most important locations are the ones where people I care about live, so I've made a geo-spatial address book. The yellow flags tell a more personal history of places that I've lived.

The New York Times has an article about men hiring photographers to stalk them paparazzi-style as they pop the question to their significant others. I came oh-so-close to doing this myself, but went with pictures just before and after, taken by me, instead. Just a note to people considering this: I have long lenses, and can stalk like a ninja.

Korie and Jesse: Love on the Tracks
Originally uploaded by carpe icthus.
I couldn't let this pass without approving comment:

An on-line EXIF viewer. If that means nothing to you, ignore this. But it's a heck of an EXIF reader, even for off-line files. Not only is ALL the data available displayed, but the site plays around with it, including telling you the distance a camera was focusing and the mathematical depth-of-field, if you feed it an unedited photo like a NEF (and, I would imagine, as long as it was taken with a lens that feeds distance info back into the camera).

New Amazon Article Up: When should I upgrade my digital camera?
Originally uploaded by carpe icthus.

Article here.

The picture, of course, shows where my money is going, and thus how personal a stake I have in this question.
This couple was so much fun -- just palpably in love, thick in the air. I'm putting together the final presentation for the couple now, but here are a couple snippets.

Statuesque
Originally uploaded by carpe icthus.

Sadly, not a self-portrait.

The school year has started, and things here are in full-gear. I don't often write about the day-to-day work I do at Columbia, but I thought yesterday provided a good case-in-point to the biggest challenge and learning experience that comes with this job -- getting good photographs of events that are important in meaning, but visually very boring. Yesterday we had a giant launch of a new national curriculum to go hand-in-hand with Spike Lee's HBO documentary of New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina, When the Levees Broke. There was an incredibly interesting panel discussion moderated by the New York Times Bob Herbert. Incredibly interesting if you were there, that is -- from a photographer's point-of-view, it's just people at a microphone talking in incredibly poor lighting. Here's a series of photographs of all the key players, to give you a sense of how I handle these situations:

Bow Before Brendan!
Originally uploaded by carpe icthus.

This one's just a lark. Brendan had a lunch party for his new satirical comic collection, "Dose!" (which is, by the way, totally hilarious), and climbed up in the DJ booth for a 30-second portrait. Of course, most people taking a silly bar portrait don't use a remote flash balanced on the turntable.
I've decided to take a chance on a new Wedding site, and put up a listing at The Wedding Party. Feel free to check out the site and, of course, to pass my listing around.
